statement.text: Acute Limb Ischemia (ALI) is a sudden decrease in limb perfusion threatening limb viability, typically <14 days duration. It is characterized by the '6 Ps' (Pain, Pallor, Pulselessness, Poikilothermia, Paresthesias, Paralysis) and requires emergent revascularization. Major causes are embolism (cardiac source) and thrombosis (in-situ on diseased artery or graft). Rutherford classification guides urgency of intervention.
statement.formal: ALI: Sudden limb hypoperfusion <14 days | 6 Ps: Pain, Pallor, Pulselessness, Poikilothermia, Paresthesias, Paralysis | Causes: Embolism (cardiac) or Thrombosis (arterial disease/graft) | Treatment: Emergent revascularization (surgical or endovascular)

explanation.intuition: Imagine suddenly cutting off the blood supply to your leg - that's ALI. Within hours, the muscles start to starve for oxygen. First you feel pain and notice the leg is cold and pale. Then nerves start to fail (numbness, tingling). Finally, muscles stop working (weakness, paralysis). Once muscles are dead, the leg is unsalvageable and needs amputation. The clock is ticking from the moment blood flow stops.
explanation.key_insight: The Rutherford classification divides ALI into viable (I), marginally threatened (IIa), immediately threatened (IIb), and irreversibly damaged (III). The key distinction is IIa vs IIb: IIa has sensory loss only and can wait hours; IIb has motor deficit and needs revascularization within 6 hours. Class III (rigor, complete paralysis) means the limb is lost - attempting revascularization risks reperfusion syndrome and death.
explanation.technical_details: Etiology: (1) Embolism (80% cardiac - AFib, recent MI, valve disease) - sudden onset, no PAD history, contralateral pulses present; (2) Thrombosis (in-situ on diseased artery) - history of claudication, bilateral disease; (3) Graft thrombosis - prior bypass surgery. Time windows: Muscle tolerates ~6 hours of warm ischemia; irreversible damage occurs by 8-12 hours. Revascularization options: surgical thromboembolectomy (Fogarty catheter), open bypass, catheter-directed thrombolysis, percutaneous mechanical thrombectomy. Fasciotomy may be needed to prevent compartment syndrome after revascularization.
common_misconceptions: All limb ischemia is acute - chronic ischemia is more common and less urgent
Pulselessness means irreversible damage - early pulselessness is expected and reversible
All ALI patients need immediate surgery - some can be managed with thrombolysis
Irreversible limb = must amputate immediately - may need to stabilize patient first

definitions_glossary.acute_limb_ischemia: Sudden decrease in limb perfusion threatening viability, <14 days
definitions_glossary.embolism: Intravascular material (usually thrombus) traveling from proximal source
definitions_glossary.thrombosis: Clot formation in-situ on diseased vessel or graft
definitions_glossary.rutherford_classification: Staging system for ALI severity guiding treatment urgency
definitions_glossary.fasciotomy: Surgical incision of fascia to relieve compartment syndrome

six_ps.description: Severe, sudden onset, worse with movement
Weakness or inability to move - motor nerve/muscle ischemia

class_I_viable.treatment: Revascularization within 6-24 hours, may use thrombolysis

class_III_irreversible.description: Major tissue loss or permanent damage inevitable
class_III_irreversible.treatment: Primary amputation, revascularization risks reperfusion syndrome

thrombosis.onset: Hours to days, may have prodrome
thrombosis.source: In-situ on diseased artery or bypass graft
thrombosis.prior_symptoms: Often history of claudication or prior intervention

definition.@value: Sudden decrease in limb perfusion threatening viability, requiring emergent revascularization

sources.citation: Rutherford RB. Clinical staging of acute limb ischemia. J Vasc Surg. 1997;26:S86.

learning_objectives: Recognize the clinical presentation of ALI
Apply the Rutherford classification to determine urgency
clinical_pearls: Motor deficit (paralysis) = immediately threatened = emergency OR now
Sensory only = marginally threatened = you have hours, not minutes
Irreversible (rigor, mottled fixed) = amputation, don't revascularize
AFib is the #1 source of embolic ALI - check for it

medicalCode.description: Embolism and thrombosis of arteries of the lower extremities
